poem:
Route 42 glides into early dawn  
its engine a low hum beneath the rising sky.  
I lean against the window’s cool glass—  
coffee steam curling in my palms,  
a faint bite of diesel on my tongue.  

We drift past a flock of geese at the curb,  
their feathers ruffled by a hesitant breeze.  
No screech of brakes here—only the steady pulse  
of tires on asphalt, indifferent to their crossing.  

Inside, fluorescent lights flicker overhead,  
casting long shadows on worn vinyl seats.  
A passenger taps fingers on a pole—  
rhythmic punctuation to the city’s heartbeat.  

At the corner, the bus slows to a hush.  
A mural blooms on a brick wall:  
neon blossoms tangled with ghostly faces,  
glistening rivulets of spray paint  
where once was only bare stone.  
We linger there, as if hypnotized  
by color bleeding into concrete.  

Then we’re off again—  
through alleyways scented with fresh rain  
and the sharp tang of graffiti solvent,  
past markets where ripe fruit spills its scent  
into the morning air.  

Children’s laughter bounces off storefronts,  
an accordion player folds notes into the breeze.  
Route 42 swerves onto a quieter street,  
where the city exhales in whispered sighs,  
and the hum of industry softens to a murmur.  

Here, the pavement feels alive beneath us,  
cracked veins filled with wildflowers and grit.  
A passenger drifts to sleep,  
eyelashes flickering like shuttered windows,  
while I watch the world unfold—  
its unpredictable choreography  
of light and shadow, motion and stillness.  

By evening, neon signs flicker on again,  
the hum of traffic blending with distant sirens.  
Route 42 glides into the dusk—  
a restless spirit guiding strangers  
through the city’s ever-shifting mosaic.
